questions.text: A 52-year-old male, non-smoker, presents with progressive shortness of breath, persistent dry cough, and chest pain. A CT scan reveals a peripheral mass in the lower lobe of left lung, and a biopsy of the nodule demonstrates a glandular pattern with mucinous differentiation, as shown in the image below. Which of the following markers is least likely to be positive in this patient's lung lesion?
Which of the following is not an IHC marker for small-cell lung carcinoma?

A 56-year-old male presents with persistent shoulder pain radiating to the ulnar aspect of the forearm and progressive weakness in his right hand. Examination reveals muscle wasting in the right hand. Imaging of the chest shows a mass at the apex of the right lung involving nearby neurovascular structures. Which syndrome is most likely associated with this presentation?

A 55-year-old woman has an incidental finding of a lung mass on imaging. CT scan reveals a well-circumscribed lesion with calcifications. Biopsy revealed spindle and epithelioid cells with an eosinophilic cytoplasm, perivascular growth, and positive HMB-45 staining. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old former shipyard worker presents with progressive dyspnea and left-sided chest pain for three months. He has a history of occupational asbestos exposure. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Imaging shows left-sided pleural thickening and effusion. Biopsy confirms mesothelioma. Which of the following statements is not accurate about mesothelioma and adenocarcinoma following asbesto exposure?

options.label: A
options.text: Adenocarcinoma often has a shorter latency period compared to mesothelioma following asbestos exposure.

options.label: B
options.text: Mesothelioma under electron microscopy, reveals short, non-branching microvilli.

options.label: C
options.text: Mesothelioma often presents with positive staining for calretinin and WT-1.

options.label: D
options.text: Adenocarcinoma is commonly associated with EGFR mutation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Mesothelioma under electron microscopy, reveals short, non-branching microvilli.
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Malignant mesothelioma

Adenocarcinoma lung

Origin

Arises from mesothelial cells lining the pleura.

Arises from glandular epithelial cells.

Association with asbestos exposure

Most specific tumours due to asbestos exposure

M/C carcinoma in asbestos exposure.

Latency period

25-45 years after asbestos exposure

10-30 years after asbestos exposure (Option A)

Specific genetic mutations

NF2, BAP1, chromosome 9p deletion

EGFR, ALK, KRAS (Option D)

Pathological features

Epithelioid, sarcomatoid, or biphasic patterns

Various growth patterns, glandular differentiation

Immunohistochemistry

Keratin, Calretinin, WT-1 (Option C), cytokeratin 5/6, podoplanin

Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1)

Electron microscopy

Long, slender, branching microvilli (Option B)

Short and non-branching microvilli

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with pleuritic chest pain and a pleural-based mass observed on imaging studies. Histopathological examination of a biopsy from the mass reveals spindle-shaped cells within a collagenous stroma. Which immunohistochemical marker would be most useful in differentiating solitary fibrous tumour (SFT) from mesothelioma?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Solitary Fibrous Tumor (SFT)

Malignant Mesothelioma

Nature of the tumour

Mostly benign, rare malignant

Malignant

Histopathology

Dense fibrous tissue, spindle cells, occasional cysts

Diffuse, invasive tumour growth across the pleural surface

Immunohistochemistry
  • Positive for CD34 and STAT6.
  • Negative for Keratin.
  • Positive for Calretinin, WT1, cytokeratin 5/6, and podoplanin.

Morphology

Tumours, often pedunculated and attached to the pleural surface, may have a whorled appearance.


 

Thick, firm, gelatinous tissue ensheathing the lung; often extensive effusion.

Microscopic appearance

Spindle cells are arranged in whorls among reticulin and collagen fibres.

Variable: Epithelioid (tubular/papillary structures), sarcomatoid (fibrosarcoma-like), or biphasic

questions.text: A 45-year-old nonsmoking woman presents with a persistent cough and hemoptysis. Imaging reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right lung. Biopsy shows cells with neuroendocrine features, including round to oval nuclei, stippled chromatin, and abundant granular cytoplasm arranged in nests and trabeculae. Which cell type is most likely involved in the origin of this patient's lung tumour?

A 50-year-old female presents with a chronic cough and recurrent episodes of wheezing. Bronchoscopy reveals a "coat button lesion" within the bronchus, as shown in the image. Biopsy of the lesion shows nesting of cells with uniform round nuclei and moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the described features?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Small Cell Carcinoma
(Option A)

Squamous Cell Carcinoma
(Option B)

Carcinoid Tumor
(Option C)

Adenocarcinoma
(Option D)

Origin

Neuroendocrine cells of the lung.

Squamous cells of the lung.

Neuroendocrine cells of bronchial epithelium.

Glandular cells of the lung.

Cells in histopathology

Small, round to oval, blue cells with scant cytoplasm and finely granular chromatin with a “salt and pepper” appearance.

Sheets of polygonal cells with keratinisation and intercellular bridges

Nesting (organoid) growth pattern with uniform round nuclei, moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm, and a “salt-and-pepper” chromatin pattern.

Glandular or epithelial cells forming acinar, papillary, or solid patterns

Mitotic rate

High

Variable

Low to moderate

Variable

Electron microscopy findings

Dense core neurosecretory granules.

Desmosomes, tonofilaments, keratinisation

Dense core neurosecretory granules.

Variable organelles, sometimes containing mucin vacuoles

IHC markers

Positive for neuroendocrine markers (e.g., chromogranin, synaptophysin).

P63, p40, CK5/6

Positive for neuroendocrine markers (e.g., chromogranin, synaptophysin)

Variable (e.g., TTF-1, Napsin A for primary lung adenocarcinoma)

questions.text: A 50-year-old heavy smoker presents with a persistent cough and unintentional weight loss. Imaging shows a right lung mass with mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Biopsy reveals small, round cells with scant cytoplasm and nuclei exhibiting a salt-and-pepper chromatin pattern. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) is positive for neuroendocrine markers. Which of the following features is incorrectly associated with this clinical condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Both glandular and squamous differentiation are seen

options.label: B
options.text: Encrustation of tumour cells along the blood vessels with DNA material

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of dense neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy

questions.correct_answer: A. Both glandular and squamous differentiation are seen

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents progressive shortness of breath, especially on exertion, fatigue, and ankle swelling. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure. Echocardiography shows right ventricular hypertrophy and elevated pulmonary artery pressure. Which of the following conditions can predispose her to this condition?

A 59-year-old heavy smoker presents with loss of appetite and a persistent cough for the past few months. Imaging reveals a central lung mass involving the right bronchus and mediastinal lymph nodes. Immunohistochemical staining of a lung mass biopsy is positive for chromogranin and synaptophysin. Which set of genes is most likely involved in the underlying pathology of this patient's condition? P53 RB L-myc

A 57-year-old male smoker with a persistent cough and weight loss is found to have a lung mass on imaging. The biopsy showed keratin pearls and intercellular bridges. Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes is highly associated with this diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH)

questions.explanation:
Type of Lung Carcinoma

Paraneoplastic Syndrome

Squamous cell carcinoma

Hypercalcemia

Adenocarcinoma

Migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome)

Small cell or oat cell Carcinoma
  • SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone secretion)
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Lambert eaton syndrome

Large cell carcinoma

Gynaecomastia

Trousseau syndrome

Trousseau sign

Troisier’s sign or Virchow node

Characterized by the elevated risk of thromboembolism in advanced cancers, driven by tumour-associated inflammation, coagulation factors (such as tissue factor and factor VIII), and procoagulants like mucin released by tumour cells.

Carpopedal spasms, which are involuntary muscle contractions of the hand and wrist, can occur when a blood pressure cuff restricts circulation to the distal arm for several minutes. This phenomenon is indicative of hypocalcemia.

Refers to a palpable, enlarged left supraclavicular lymph node and is a clinical indicator of metastatic cancer, suggesting the spread of the tumour to the supraclavicular lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male smoker presents with a persistent cough and weight loss. Imaging reveals a lung mass in the upper lobe of the right lung. The biopsy reveals typical features, including keratin pearls, intercellular bridges, and nests of malignant squamous cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Based on this scenario, which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Keratin pearls are not seen in poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.

options.label: B
options.text: p40 is the best marker for squamous cell carcinoma.

options.label: C
options.text: Squamous dysplasia is a precursor lesion of squamous cell carcinoma

options.label: D
options.text: The squamous cell carcinoma described is likely a peripheral lung lesion.

questions.correct_answer: D. The squamous cell carcinoma described is likely a peripheral lung lesion.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male smoker presents with a persistent cough and mild shortness of breath. Chest imaging reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule. A biopsy is performed, and a histopathological examination of the lung tissue is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Diffuse idiopathic pulmonary neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia

questions.text: A 55-year-old male smoker presents to the clinic with chronic cough and hemoptysis. He has been smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years. Upon further evaluation, a biopsy reveals lung carcinoma. Which of the following statements regarding risk factors for lung carcinoma is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Smoking is a major risk factor for squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

options.label: B
options.text: Smoking has no association with adenocarcinoma of the lung.

options.label: C
options.text: Smoking is a significant risk factor for small-cell lung carcinoma.

options.label: D
options.text: Asbestosis exposure, along with smoking, multiplies the risk of lung cancer.

questions.correct_answer: B. Smoking has no association with adenocarcinoma of the lung.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with severe shortness of breath, cough, and fever after recent bacterial pneumonia. Physical examination shows tachypnea, hypoxia, and diffuse crackles on chest auscultation. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral opacities suggestive of pulmonary oedema. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy shows congested, edematous lungs with inflammation. Which histopathological finding is characteristic of the acute exudative stage in this patient's lung injury?

options.label: B
options.text: Formation of fibrotic thickening in the alveolar septa

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls

options.label: D
options.text: Resolution of granulation tissue in the alveolar spaces

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls
questions.explanation:
Stage

Features

1. Acute Exudative Stage
  • Lungs appear heavy, firm, red, and boggy.
  • Manifestations include congestion, interstitial and intra-alveolar oedema, inflammation, fibrin deposition, and diffuse alveolar damage.
  • Alveolar walls are lined with “waxy hyaline membranes” composed of fibrin-rich oedema fluid mixed with remnants of necrotic epithelial cells.

2. Proliferative or Organizing Stage
  • Proliferation of Type II pneumocytes.
  • Granulation tissue forms in the alveolar walls and spaces.

3. Late Fibrotic Stage
  • Fibrotic thickening of alveolar septa indicates persistent fibrosis and scarring that may develop in some cases of lung injury.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the pathogenesis sequence of non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema (NCPE) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is incorrect? Endothelial activation is the hallmark of pathogenesis. Release of cytokines by alveolar epithelial cells Macrophage activation resulting in the release of IL-8 and TNF Recruitment of lymphocytes by IL-8

A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive shortness of breath and fatigue. On examination, she has elevated jugular venous pressure and a loud pulmonary component of the second heart sound. Echocardiography reveals right ventricular hypertrophy and dilation. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the vascular changes of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: BMPR2 mutations result in endothelial and vascular smooth muscle cell apoptosis.

options.label: B
options.text: Classic atherosclerotic changes are commonly observed in pulmonary arteries.

options.label: C
options.text: Plexiform lesions are early changes of pulmonary hypertension.

options.label: D
options.text: Pulmonary arterioles show medial hypertrophy and intimal fibrosis, narrowing the lumens.

questions.correct_answer: D. Pulmonary arterioles show medial hypertrophy and intimal fibrosis, narrowing the lumens.
